guide.title: Gentoo Documentation Project Formatting Guide
guide.abstract: This guide will cover the formatting basics for GDP documentation.

body.p: The purpose of this guide is to provide some examples of proper formatting for GDP (Gentoo Documentation Project) documentation. Before reading this guide, it is expected that you have read both the XML Guide and the Documentation Policy.

Since the main goal of the GDP is to create clear and concise documentation, it comes as no big surprise that our documentation follows a strict set of formatting guidelines. Not only do these guidelines ensure that our documentation is structurally clear, but they keep the documentation portable, enabling the documentation to be migrated with website changes and transformed into a number of different formats, such as Postscript or PDF.

The layout of a basic GDP guide is very hierarchial. The overall guide is contained in a guide tag, with main topics in chapter tags, and sub topics in section tags contained within the greater chapter tags. Basically, the form of a document follows much that of a college type outline:

section.title: Using the right tags in the right place

body.p: The Gentoo/ GDP XML format has a ton of tags that do many nifty things. The problem is, there are so many tags that do similar tasks, it is hard to know which tags should be used where. For starters, the i tags are used to highlight text for emphasis. For example: Make sure you never do rm -rf /. The e tag on the other hand, italizes words for a less enhancing effect. For example: It is highly recommended to remove Windows in great times of frustration. As far as emphasizing commands, the c tag is the correct tag to use. For example: Please run etc-update after each emerge -u world, or suffer the wrath of the bug-wranglers.

Additionally, in order to keep W3C compliance, do not place note, warn, info, etc, tags inside of a p tag. Please be smart with how you write your guides, and if you are ever in doubt of validility, check the document (in its HTML form) with the W3C validator.
pre tags are usually used to insert examples into documents. A pre tag in a live document would look like this:
body.pre: Hi there! Formatting does matter here...
body.p: The first thing that you probably noticed was that the tabbed in words are, well, tabbed in. Reason being, formatting does matter in pre tags. For example, I can type a paragraph inside of a p tag with indents, returns at the end of lines, etc. As you well know, those formatting attributes are not picked up by the XML processing. pre tags are special due to the fact that they do pick up formatting attributes, as depicted above. Moral of the story? To maintain proper code indentation, indent the tag line (<pre caption = "foo">), but not the content contained within, except of course if you mean to have the pre content formatted.

Secondly, all pre tags are to have a caption. If you look at the above example, that pre container has the caption of I am a pre tag. This is done by giving the caption argument to the tag, so the tag declaration looks like so:
body.pre: <pre caption = "Example pre tag and caption"> Pre text...FOO! <pre>
body.p: Last, but surely not least, keep the length of your pre content to under 80 characters!!! I cannot stress the importance of this. If the content is over 80 characters, printed documentation becomes unreadable. Please, don't make me yell at you for this!
Of course, if in doubt, you can always check the existing documentation that resides in CVS.

For the sake of us developers, please linebreak when your line of text is at about 80 characters. What this means is, hit return when you are typing every once and awhile. Remember, formatting only matters in pre tags, so linebreak all that you want in the other tags!

XML documentation is code, so please, please, indent correctly. All of our guides use a tabspace setting of 4. In vim this would be set by entering command mode, and then doing :set ts=4. If you don't use vim, you are not exempt. Enough said, nothing more to see here, moving on.

All GDP documentation must be encoded in the UTF-8 encoding scheme. Encoding all documentation UTF-8 makes everyone's lives easier, especially the translators, as UTF-8 is easily portable across languages. An easy way to format your document in UTF-8 is to use iconv:

body.p: If you have any questions or concerns about this document, or the formatting process, feel free to contact the GDP team using the gentoo-doc@gentoo.org mailinglist.
